Bodhisattvas seek wealth through right livelihood in villages, not through wrong livelihood, in accordance with [the Dharma], not going against it, not oppressing sentient beings.

They seek wealth and goods to practice giving, not for the sake of respect, offerings, fame, etc., not out of shame or fear, not for the sake of rewards, not for rebirth in the heavens, not out of flattery.
They do not criticize or praise those who uphold precepts or violate precepts, whether they are known or unknown, and with an impartial mind, they make offerings, respect, revere, and praise them.
They also have deep respect, affection, and faith towards those who uphold precepts or violate precepts, whether they are close or not, known or unknown, enemies or not.

This bodhisattva should always give according to what he has. If he has little, he gives little; if he has much, he gives much; if he has coarse [goods], he gives coarse [goods]; if he has fine [goods], he gives fine [goods]; if he has wonderful [goods], he gives wonderful [goods]; if he has not wonderful [goods], he gives not wonderful [goods].
If one were to offer delicious food and drink worth a hundred thousand, or even a single coin divided into sixteen parts, with a joyful mind, there is no difference in merit.
Good man!
This bodhisattva, to those who beg for food, gives food to fulfill the power of omniscience.
To those who beg for drink, he gives drink to cut off the thirst and craving of sentient beings.
To those who beg for clothing, he gives clothing to obtain the unsurpassed robe of shame and conscience.
To those who beg for vehicles, he gives vehicles to obtain the bodhisattva vehicle and the Buddha vehicle.
To those who beg for incense, he gives incense to obtain the fragrance of the precepts of right enlightenment.
To those who beg for flowers, he gives flowers to obtain the seven-fold enlightenment flower of the TathÄgata.
To those who beg for powdered incense, he gives powdered incense to obtain the elimination of all sentient beings' unwholesome fragrances.
To those who beg for ointments, he gives ointments to obtain a body with the fragrance of precepts without deficiency.
If they need a canopy, they give a canopy, in order to extinguish the afflictions of sentient beings.
If they need leather shoes, they give leather shoes, in order to receive immeasurable wisdom and bliss.
If they need a bed, they give a bed, in order to enable sentient beings to attain the blissful power of Åšakra, BrahmÄ, and the sages.
If they need a seat, they give a seat, in order to sit under the bodhi tree, with the seats of the mÄras and afflictions unable to disturb their sitting.
If they need a house, they give a house, in order to enable sentient beings to attain a place of refuge, to be fearless, and to attain the power of selflessness.
They offer beautiful gardens and groves to the Buddha and Saá¹…gha, in order to attain the power of the unsurpassed tranquil meditation.

They hold wonderful offerings and various adornments to offer to the Buddha's stÅ«pas and temples, in order to attain the power of a great man with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics.
If they light lamps and offer light in the Buddha's stÅ«pas and dark paths, it is in order to attain the immeasurable light of the Buddha's eye.
With various kinds of music, they make offerings to the Three Jewels, in order to attain immeasurable heavenly ears.
They give away robes and alms bowls, in order to attain the unsurpassed dignity of upholding the precepts.
They give away fans, wash basins, and other utensils, in order to enable sentient beings to attain coolness and purity.
They give away paper, pens, ink, and high seats, in order to attain the unsurpassed great wisdom.
They give medicine to the sick, in order to eliminate the afflictions of sentient beings.
They give away land, in order to enable sentient beings to attain the nectar realm of the Three Vehicles.
They build stupas and images, in order to enable sentient beings to listen to the true Dharma.
They quickly give away all their possessions, in order to attain the power of swift spiritual abilities.
Their giving is pure, in order to avoid obstacles on the unsurpassed path.
They give continuously without interruption, in order to attain the power of uninterrupted eloquence.
They give according to their wishes, in order to enable sentient beings to attain great compassion.
Not oppressing people to seek wealth and use it for giving, in order to enable the mÄras and non-Buddhists to be unable to destroy and disturb, and naturally attain the unsurpassed path.
Bodhisattvas should practice giving as explained above.

If bodhisattvas wish to make the above kinds of giving, if they do not have wealth themselves they should give rise to the mind of giving, wishing to reveal it to immeasurable and boundless sentient beings.

With power or without power, giving as above is my good practice, I am wonderfully superior, this is my treasure, able to cause all sentient beings in the world to attain all kinds of happiness, namely the happiness of being able to unite.
Able to give up everything without any doubt, all the wishes they have will be fulfilled and they will attain the practice of peace and happiness.

If there are sentient beings in the world who wish to obtain the things they need, I will satisfy them and give them precious treasures, gold, silver, clothing, money, and wealth piled up like mountains, and food and drink as abundant as the great ocean, immeasurable and boundless.
This bodhisattva, day and night, at each of the three times, with the fruits and rewards obtained from his own practice of giving wealth and the Dharma, wishes to share them with all sentient beings.
May all sentient beings in the past, future, and present, who practice, be born in wonderful buddha-lands and attain the bliss of transcendence.
Although this person practices such giving, he never hopes for or seeks its fruits and rewards.
He reveals such skillful means in order to transform sentient beings and cause them to enter the good Dharma.
When this bodhisattva practices giving, he wishes for all sentient beings to attain liberation and to attain omniscience in order to perfect all the Buddha's teachings.
If one practices giving and has already given, one also wishes sentient beings to attain liberation and attain omniscience in order to be endowed with all the Buddha's teachings.
If such giving is without power and one is unable to learn it or give away wealth,
this bodhisattva should contemplate in the following way:
'I should now diligently apply effort, gradually and over time, to eliminate the defilements of stinginess and greed.

I should diligently apply effort, gradually and over time, to learn to give away wealth and always allow my mind of giving to increase and expand, even to the point of being born again, never with a lazy mind but always joyful.'

In this way, the bodhisattva gives rise to the mind of enlightenment, contemplates the mind of enlightenment, cultivates the mind of enlightenment, aspires to enlightenment, and seeks enlightenment. This is called the bodhisattva's immeasurable and incalculable great giving, great relinquishing, and great emergence.
Why is it so?
Such giving is the most supreme and foremost of all giving.
May I in the future rain down the Dharma rain and the nectar rain, bestow the Dharma rain and the nectar rain, and manifest the Dharma rain and the nectar rain among all sentient beings in the world.
SubÄhu!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who practice giving in this way do not consider it difficult, but rather take joy in it, and quickly perfect the perfection of generosity.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas cannot give their own bodies and limbs to beggars, whether by cutting themselves or by instructing others to cut them.
Why is this?
If they were to accomplish this deed, it would cause those beggars to experience immeasurable suffering in the great hells.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should not be stingy with their own bodies and limbs.
Why is this?
It is in order to cause the beggars to abandon their vast unwholesome actions.

If there are beggars who come to the bodhisattva and beg for what they need, at that time the bodhisattva should not forcefully coerce his parents, wife, children, relatives, servants, and attendants to take their wealth and give it to others, causing them to be impoverished.
Why is this?
Because the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva wishes to cultivate an attitude of impartial kindness towards all sentient beings.

If the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva does not forcefully take the wealth of his parents, wife, children, relatives, servants, and attendants to give in charity, at that time the bodhisattva attains a compassionate mind towards sentient beings.
Good man!

The bodhisattva should not have a stingy mind towards other sentient beings, and should not take wealth by coercing other sentient beings to give in charity. This is not praised by the buddhas, let alone cutting off one's own limbs to give to others.
This is called the bodhisattva's perfection of generosity.

This bodhisattva, for the rest of his life, does not himself kill, does not teach others to kill, and does not wish to kill.ğŸ”½He does not himself steal, does not teach others to steal, and does not wish to steal.
He does not himself engage in sexual misconduct, does not teach others to engage in sexual misconduct, and does not wish to engage in sexual misconduct.
He does not himself lie, does not teach others to lie, and does not wish to lie.
For the rest of his life, he does not himself drink alcohol, does not teach others to drink alcohol, and does not wish to drink alcohol.
This bodhisattva always firmly upholds these five precepts, always mindful of them, not lax or deficient, diligently applying himself.

In this way, he permanently cuts off and distances himself from frightening others, binding and imprisoning them, beating and punishing them, and the same is true for divisive speech, harsh speech, false speech, and frivolous speech.
This bodhisattva thinks like this:
'I should give rise to a mind of love and concern for all sentient beings, just as parents love and care for their only child.
If my parents were to harm me with various painful things such as bows, arrows, swords, and staves, I would never retaliate.
I should treat all sentient beings as parents love their only child.'
It is like parents and children who have been separated for a long time suddenly seeing each other again, their hearts filled with immeasurable joy and excitement.

In the same way, when a bodhisattva sees all sentient beings, his mind is filled with joy in the same way.ğŸ”½This bodhisattva upholds the precept against killing, wishing to enable sentient beings to abide in the precept against killing without further learning.ğŸ”½This bodhisattva upholds the precept against stealing, wishing to enable sentient beings to abide in the precept against stealing without further learning.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept against sexual misconduct, wishing to enable sentient beings to abide in the precept against sexual misconduct without further learning.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept against false speech in order to enable sentient beings to abide in the precept of true speech of the stage of no-more-learning.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept against drinking alcohol in order to enable sentient beings to abide in the precept against drinking alcohol of the stage of no-more-learning.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept against frightening [others] in order to accomplish the adamantine samÄdhi.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept against harsh speech in order to attain the five kinds of Brahma sounds.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept of protecting others' possessions and preventing leakage, in order to attain the concentration of unsurpassed enlightenment.
If other beings, women, wives, or children are detained, at that time the bodhisattva rescues and liberates them, in order to attain the concentration of the unimpaired Dharma.
This bodhisattva, if encouraging others to release them, is in order to attain mastery of the mind.
This bodhisattva, if releasing himself or encouraging others to release, is in order to sit under the bodhi tree and destroy all the bonds and afflictions of Mara.
This bodhisattva, if seeing beings in prison, either releasing himself or encouraging others to release, is in order to attain mastery of the mind without obstruction.
If this bodhisattva sees sentient beings about to be whipped or beaten, he himself releases them and encourages others to release them, in order to attain the four forms of fearlessness.
If this bodhisattva sees sentient beings about to be executed, he himself releases them and encourages others to release them, in order to attain the four forms of the Dharma body.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept of non-deception, in order to sit under the bodhi tree and on the lion seat, and for all mÄras and afflictions to be unable to obstruct him, and to attain the samÄdhi of the Dharma.
This bodhisattva skillfully reconciles disputes and gives rise to joy exclusively, in order to attain the indestructible great assembly of sages.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept of loving speech, wishing to cause all sentient beings to hear good words and joyfully experience happiness with their minds.
This bodhisattva speaks in accordance with loving speech, wishing to cause his words to not be empty.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept of reciting the Buddha's literary expressions, in order to attain the sagely person's majestic virtue and accomplish the great assembly.

This bodhisattva upholds the five-limbed prostration to all Buddhas, Dharma, and Sangha in the three periods of time, in all worlds, past, present, and future, in order to attain the indestructible lion seat under the bodhi tree, and abides single-mindedly in faith, diligence, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom, in order to attain the certainty of the Dharma.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept of sweeping and circumambulating the stupa in the three periods of time, in order to attain all the Buddha's teachings in their entirety.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept of praising the Sangha, in order to be surrounded by the great assembly.ğŸ”½This bodhisattva upholds the precept of taking refuge in the Three Jewels in the three periods of time, in order to enable all sentient beings to attain unsurpassed refuge.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept of wishing for the Buddha, Dharma, Sangha, and bodhisattvas to always be present and never empty in the world in the three periods of time, in order to attain the bliss of unsurpassed enlightenment.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept of exhorting all buddhas to expound the Dharma at the three times, in order to attain the ten abodes and rain down the Dharma rain.
This bodhisattva upholds the precept of repenting of all offenses, abandoning all evil and defiled actions at the three times, in order to eradicate all habitual tendencies of craving.

This bodhisattva upholds the precept of aspiring for all the wholesome roots of the buddhas, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and bodhisattvas in the holy assemblies of the past, future, and present, as well as the wholesome roots of sentient beings in the six destinies, wherever they may be, at the three times, in order to utilize them for unsurpassed enlightenment.

If this bodhisattva sees those who are heedless and forgetful, namely those who have lost the meaning of the three vehicles in the present and future, he wishes to arouse mindfulness and uphold it so that it is not lost.
This bodhisattva upholds the precepts of listening to the Dharma, collecting the Dharma, and expounding the Dharma, in order to attain the four unobstructed eloquences in their entirety.

This bodhisattva upholds the wholesome roots of all bodily, verbal, and mental actions, embraces them, and practices them, in order to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation and attain omniscience, and to attain all the Buddha's teachings in their entirety.

Such wholesome roots, he wishes to practice for the sake of all sentient beings, in order to enable sentient beings to attain liberation, attain omniscience, and attain all the Buddha's teachings in their entirety.
Thus he upholds the precepts without deficiency, without violation, without confusion.
If he is powerless and unable to practice, this bodhisattva should think like this:
'Now I should diligently apply effort, gradually and progressively distancing myself from killing and other unwholesome dharmas.

I further redoubled my diligence, gradually and gradually learning to uphold the precepts well, causing them to increase and be fulfilled, and even in future lives I will never be lazy or give rise to sorrow.'
Good Arm!

In this way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to the mind of enlightenment, contemplate the mind of enlightenment, cultivate the path of enlightenment, aspire to enlightenment, and seek enlightenment. This is called the immeasurable and boundless wholesome roots of upholding the precepts.
Why is this?
Because such upholding of the precepts is the most supreme and foremost of all wholesome precepts.

Upholding these precepts, one wishes to cause all sentient beings in the world to give rise to the precepts without outflows, to give rise to the precepts without further learning, to give rise to the precepts without outflows, and to give rise to the precepts without further learning.

In this way, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not consider upholding these precepts to be difficult, but rather take joy in them, and quickly perfect the perfection of morality.

How do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas perfect the pÄramitÄ of forbearance?

If the bodhisattva's own retinue or other sentient beings come to deprive the bodhisattva of life, at that time the bodhisattva will never give rise to a mind of anger or retaliation towards these matters.

There may be others who come to deprive the bodhisattva of wealth, even to his wife and children, or who speak divisive words, harsh words, lies, or frivolous speech, or who frighten, bind, imprison, whip, or execute the bodhisattva with various kinds of suffering.
At that time the bodhisattva will also not give rise to a mind of retaliation.

If they deprive one of life, all possessions, even one's wife and children, or speak divisive words, harsh words, lies, or frivolous speech, frighten, bind, imprison, whip, or execute [one], the bodhisattva contemplates such matters thus: These are the retributions of my evil conduct and unwholesome karma. I myself create and myself experience [the results]. Either in past lives or in the present life, if I have previously created [evil], I now experience the retribution.
How can I now be angry with others about my own karmic retribution?
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

If others take away my life, wealth, even my wife and children, if they speak slander, harsh words, lies, and frivolous speech, if they frighten, bind, imprison, whip, or execute me, I should not be angry or harm others, or bind my enemies.
Why is it so?

I now experience a little suffering and pain, which I do not love, enjoy, or find agreeable. How can I give rise to anger and harm others, and in the future receive immeasurable, boundless, hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of sufferings and pains as retribution, which I do not love, enjoy, or find agreeable?
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva thinks like this:

'Because there is life, one cuts off life; because there is wealth, one seizes wealth; because there are wives and children, one takes away their wives and children; because there is the faculty of hearing, one hears slander, harsh words, lies, and frivolous speech; because there is this body, there is fear, bondage, imprisonment, beating, and death.
Now I myself experience the faculty of life, the faculty of hearing, and the suffering of the body. How can I retaliate with anger towards others?'
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate in this way:
'The faculty of the eye is precisely the earth element, precisely one's own property, precisely the dharma realm, precisely one's own nature.
The nature of wetness is water, the nature of heat is fire, and the nature of movement is wind, which is precisely one's own property, precisely the dharma realm, precisely one's own nature.
In this way, all life is precisely the dharma of destruction, the dharma of extinction, the dharma of exhaustion.
In this way, all faculties are the dharma of suffering, the dharma of contact with suffering, the dharma of experiencing suffering.'
The entire body is the Dharma of suffering, the Dharma of being touched by suffering, the Dharma of experiencing suffering, which is one's own property, the Dharma realm, and one's own nature.

This life of mine now is the Dharma of destruction, the Dharma of extinction, the Dharma of exhaustion, the Dharma of suffering. These six faculties are the Dharma of being touched by suffering, the Dharma of being touched by evil.
How can I now, regarding this life of mine which is the Dharma of destruction, the Dharma of extinction, the Dharma of exhaustion, give rise to anger and harm others, and bind my enemies?
Why is it so?
It is one's own property, the Dharma realm, and one's own nature.' Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate like this:ğŸ”½The inner eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are not the self and not the possessions of the self;
The outer eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are also not the self and not the possessions of the self.
How can a person of clear wisdom, regarding these six faculties that are neither self nor belonging to self, adorn and become attached to them, and give rise to anger and harm others?
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate in this way:

'The suffering of humans is slight, the suffering of hungry ghosts is much more, the suffering of animals increases even more, and the suffering and distress of hell beings is immeasurable, boundless, and incalculably more.
If one does not wish to experience even slight suffering among humans, how much more so the immeasurable suffering and distress to be experienced in the three evil destinies in the future!
Therefore, I should not give rise to anger and harm others now.'
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate in this way:
'If I can now benefit even one person, I should not give rise to anger towards others, harm others, or bind my enemies.

How much more so for me, who will benefit immeasurable sentient beings in all worlds with the profound Dharma meaning, generate great adornments, and after generating great adornments, attain predictions and enter the Great Vehicle to attain the unsurpassed Buddha Dharma in its entirety.

Within this Buddha Dharma, one should not be intolerant, harm others, be jealous, or engage in disputes. Here, one should practice patience and benefit others, skillfully reconcile disputes, and be free from jealousy.
Good Bima!

If there are good men and good women who experience various sufferings even in AvÄ«ci Hell, one should not give rise to anger, harm, or slander towards even one's enemies, let alone give rise to anger and harm others when experiencing slight suffering among humans?

When these good men and good women are angered by others, scolded, reviled, slandered, or disparaged, they should endure all such evils, give rise to a compassionate mind that is pure and unstained, and wish to attain the mind of the TathÄgata.

When this bodhisattva is beaten, struck, threatened, bound, or imprisoned, he should endure all of this and give rise to a compassionate mind, in order to destroy the darkness of ignorance and the shell of afflictions in a single thought.
This bodhisattva practices forbearance and compassion, wishing to enable all sentient beings to end attachment and anger.
When his ears are cut off, he also practices forbearance and gives rise to a compassionate mind, wishing to enable all sentient beings to hear the Dharma and develop faith.
When his nose is cut off, he also practices forbearance and gives rise to a compassionate mind, in order to receive the fragrance of the unsurpassed precepts of dignity.
When his feet are cut off, he also practices forbearance and gives rise to a compassionate mind, in order to attain the four bases of supernatural power of the TathÄgata.
When his hands are cut off, he also practices forbearance and gives rise to a compassionate mind, in order to gather in all sentient beings and attain tranquility.
When his limbs and joints are cut apart, he also practices forbearance and gives rise to a compassionate mind, in order to be fully endowed with the six perfections.
When having their eyes gouged out, they also practice patience and give rise to a compassionate mind, in order to attain the eye of wisdom.
When having their heads cut off, they also practice patience and give rise to a compassionate mind, in order to attain the head of omniscience of the TathÄgata.

This bodhisattva thus practices patience and directs his thoughts towards it, vowing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation, in order to attain omniscience and perfect all the qualities of a buddha.
Such is patience.
I now direct my thoughts towards it, vowing to enable all sentient beings to attain liberation, in order to attain omniscience and perfect the qualities of a buddha.
Such is patience, unbroken, unflawed, and untroubled. If one is powerless and unable to practice, at that time the bodhisattva should think like this:
'I should now redouble my efforts, gradually distancing myself from the practice of impatience.'

Now I will diligently apply myself to make progress, gradually and progressively learning patience, causing this patience to increase and become complete, and never be lazy or give rise to sorrow until the end of my life.

In this way, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to the mind of enlightenment, contemplate the mind of enlightenment, cultivate the mind of enlightenment, aspire to enlightenment, and seek enlightenment. These bodhisattvas give rise to correct practices such as these, immeasurable, boundless, and incalculable good forbearances, wishing to cause all sentient beings in the world to give rise to uncontaminated patience, give rise to unlearned patience, give rise to uncontaminated patience, and give rise to unlearned patience.
SubÄhu!
In this way, Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice patience, not considering it difficult, but taking joy in it, and quickly perfecting the perfection of forbearance.
SubÄhu!
How do Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas perfect the perfection of vigor?
SubÄhu!
This bodhisattva should contemplate in this way:
'Now in each of the ten directions, there are innumerable worlds, and in each world, there are innumerable and boundless sentient beings gathered, without limit.
I should now arouse the adornments to enable these sentient beings to attain great benefits and also to attain happiness.

Furthermore, because of observing and knowing the Dharma that is the basis for the benefit and happiness of innumerable sentient beings, and because of arousing the Dharma of wholesome roots, I, for innumerable days and nights, whether my mind is negligent, or I give rise to other thoughts, or when I am sleeping, constantly in each moment of thought increase in merit, and in each moment of thought arouse innumerable wholesome roots that are the resources for bodhi.
I should now know that because of arousing and increasing innumerable wholesome roots in each moment of thought, it will not be difficult to accomplish supreme perfect enlightenment.'
Now, for this reason, I see that it is very easy to encounter bodhisattvas. Therefore, those who wish to attain the unsurpassed path should not be lazy for as long as they live.
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate like this:

'If a bodhisattva can cause the beings of one world to be free from all suffering among the beings of immeasurable and boundless worlds, I would still arouse immeasurable wholesome roots in each and every thought, let alone causing the beings of immeasurable and boundless worlds to be far removed from and eliminate the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, separation from loved ones, encountering the hateful, and the three evil destinies.'
Furthermore, SubÄhu!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should contemplate like this:

'If a bodhisattva mahÄsattva in a single thought wishes to cause the sentient beings in innumerable worlds to be free from and eliminate all suffering, this bodhisattva will also in a single thought generate and increase immeasurable wholesome roots, let alone wishing to cause the sentient beings in innumerable worlds for innumerable, boundless asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas in the future to be free from and eliminate the suffering of birth, old age, sickness, and death, separation from loved ones, encountering the unpleasant, and the three evil destinies.
